text: Keg @ Karben4. Deep reddish pour with a small head. Loads of caramel and toffee on the nose. Honeyed brown red. Soft red fruits. Similar flavor. Plenty of caramel dipped raisin. Lightly toasty. Subtle, earthy hop character. rich finish. Full body, smooth.

Served from bottle into glass at home. Pours amber brown in color, ruby tinted, low clarity, with small tan colored head. Deep fruity aroma, like dried cherries, with caramel malt character. No hop aroma detected. Flavor is primarily clean caramel maltiness with some light fruitiness. Low bitterness and mild sweetness. No alcohol flavor detected. Medium full body with medium low carbonation. Overall this beer is interesting. The lack of hops in both aroma and flavor is surprising and results in a sweet malty beer. Intensity of flavor is also lacking for an imperial and the alcohol strength is not apparent. Even with the deviations from style expectations, this beer is enjoyable and easily drinkable.

As delicious a red ale as Ive come across owing largely to the generous malt bill to give it a smooth, sweet character without coming across as heavy. Theres even the hops squinting through at the end with mild bitterness to further balance the effort. Ive not had many from Karben4 and this one makes me want to seek out more.
Aroma is a mix of English malts and complex toffee, caramel and nutty. The flavor is nutty malts, toffee/caramel, fruit/dark fruit and a mix of tart and slight earthiness in the finish.

Sampled from the tap at the brewpub. Pours a near clear amber with a tan head that dissipates to the edges laces slightly. Aroma has some dark fruits, sweet grains and toffee supporting. Flavor has sweet grains and toffee supporting with a hint of graham cracker and dark fruit.
A pretty decent red ale. Much more caramel, even dark fruit flavor than your typical red. Courtesy of Josh in 2016.

aroma is super malty and sweet. flavor is sweet, malty, and carmellly. little smokey flavors as well. pours reddish brown with a thin tan head. had out of a bottle in lake geneva. decent beer..not my style.

Deep dark, super red opaque pour with a single finger, tan head resting on top. Aroma has a ton of caramel. Medium bodied. Taste is big time caramel malt bomb. Just a blast of caramel. No yeast character here, just sweetness. No lace present. Nothing wrong with this beer, just not my cup of tea.

Non Beer Trip Beer Trip Beer #51. Keg at Whole Foods Wauwatosa, 3/10/16. Clear dark copper, large creamy off-white head, good retention. Aroma of earth, toffee, caramel. The taste is cherries, toffee, caramel, earth. Medium bodied, well balanced.

12 oz bottle, sampled in a rounded whisky glass, from 6 pack purchased at Willy St Co-Op (West), Middlteon WI. I guess I just have to face the fact that, after 37 tries and more than a decade, I just dont much like Irish Ales. Theres something sticky and disgusting and cloying about them, often; that or the opposite, a thin astringency; for whatever reason, I rarely find the sweet-dry balance in this style to work for me. This one alas is no exception. The color is nice enough, a deep red-burgundy, with just a bit of head which dissipates rapidly. Aroma of caramel, grape and vanilla is quite sweet and dessert-like, also lightly smoky, pleasing on its own but presaging problems to come...sipping it we get a mouthfeel that is simultaneously thick, cloying and syrupy - but grows rapidly watery towards the end. Very sweet, almost Port-like flavor, with some raisin and maple hints, and an unfortunate funky herbal/manure character that appears in the middle that is not in keeping with this style or the thickness of the front-palate experience. Its very hard to describe, to me this seems like a mixture between a Scotch ale and an unblended Lambic - and these are two great tastes that DO NOT taste great together. Hopefully the last Irish I try for a while. Well, beer anyway.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2016 Pours dark mahogany, brief head. Light, malty aroma. Flavor, pleasantly smokey and lightly sweet, malty, faint hop finish. Palate is lighter then expected.. not a negative. Overall, fairly distinctive... suggests some very interesting food pairings. Note: to get the nuances, dont over chill.

Pours a dark coppery reddish color with ivory colored head. Pine, toffee, dark fruits, and some floral notes on the nose; follows onto the palate. Full bodied. Finishes with pine and some caramel malt.
Tap @ 3 Cellars. Nice maroon color. Figs, toffee. Very warm flavor envelopes the senses. Not too shabby.

Yup. Sexy as hell indeed. I didn't rate it at the time, but have had it at the brewery as well. Just as good in the bottle. Toffee and raisin, just got some bitter chocolate. Enough hop to balance it, but it almost gets too sweet. Almost. A very solid beer. Everything seems to get put into barrels these days, I'd be interested what this would do. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Toast smoke aroma. Sweet smoke Carmel enjoyable. Aroma smoke. Very balanced. High abv though for the beer. At brewery

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On-tap, this pours a dark brown color with a slight head. The aroma is full of toffee, caramel, and raisin. The flavor is bold but yet fairly light for flavor. Interesting for the style.

Sample at the brewpub. Came regular and nitro. Certainly differences between the two. The nitro brings out ,ore sweetness and cocoa. It is a bit like drinking sugar toast with covoa on it. The rehular is maltier in that Irish style. Quite smooth and just a bit earthy. Both versions are nice.
Draft at the source. Hazy deep amber maroon color. Aroma of toasted caramel. Taste is bittersweet caramel. Nice.

On tap at The Majestic Theatre bar for Derby viewing and the second day of Madisons Craft Beer Week. Dispensed to plastic, showing a deep, ruby highlighted, brown tone, with some quickly diminishing, tan head froth, but a persistent ring & film, and spots & streaks of lacing. The nose was toasted, with a touch of roastiness, light grain, subtle spice, and toffee. Medium bodied, with decent carbonation, the taste continued the pleasant malt, and dark caramel/toffee sweetness, and included a moderate, roasted & earthy hop bitterness. The plastic might not have done it full justice presentation-wise, but quite tasty, nonetheless.
On tap at the source. Nice nose; nuts, apricot, some toffee. Taste is all toffee, and some dark fruit with alcohol. Interesting mahogany pour. American Strongish. 13.5

Dark amber with off white head. Mild lacing...lite head retention. Coffee, caramel, and chocolate aroma. Medium bodied, malt sweet, mild dark fruit, slightly watery, mild dry note on finish. Lite-medium lemony bitterness. 



---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Deep red-brown. Nose of nice fruity toasted malt. Flavor is more fruity malt (cherry, plum) with a very faint not-quite-roasted finish. Lingering toast and fruit. Lightly sweet. Another winner.
First of all this is not a standard Red. The menu at Karben4 states 7.5abv. Delicious

Sample at the brewpub. Dark reddish-amber color with a medium off-white head that diminishes steadily to an outer ring. Strings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of malt, toffee and slight hops. Light to medium body with flavors of biscuit malt, caramel and hops. The finish is sweet malt up front with a mild hoppy aftertaste. Decent overall.
Draft. Brown/amber with thin head. Toasted malt, caramel, and raisins. Medium body, toasted malt, dark fruits, bread, and a bitter hop finish. Also a hint of alcohol.
Draft. DArk red pour, menu said 7.5%. Definitely like some kind of imperial red. HEavy sweetness with a weird nougat typ flavor.

5 oz. pour, on tap at the brewpub. Consumed on 7-26-14. Pours a reddish medium to dark brown with beige head. Nice, reddish hue to the liquid. Sweet aroma features a pretzel scent. Malty, burnt caramel taste. Fine but unremarkable palate. Decent beer but didnt inspire me.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2014 On tap at brewery and later from growler. Yeah I had to buy a growler, so good sign there. This is a dark reddish beer with an off white head. The aroma can be of caramel, earthy hops, and sweetness. Taste is great, this is a very malty flavorful brew, much more dynamic malt flavor than I was expecting for a red ale. Caramel, hints of earth, raisin, faint probably Old world hops. Finish is a lingering malty sweetness, yet quite drinkable. I have noticed slight variations after having been exposed to this brew a few different times over the past year, but still always enjoyable. 6-2-2014 had in tap at Brews Brothers, this is becoming one of my favorite malty beers. Strong dynamic malt flavor and aroma. So good! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at the brewery. Comes reddish brown with a small tan head. Aroma of malt, caramel, and fruit. Taste is malt, fruit, caramel, and a touch of chocolate. On the sweet side, but very drinkable.

Very lean and clean, almost too clean, gentle malt-forward red ale with a shy UK leaning biscuit malt and earthy hop profile. Clean brewing job, but again missing some (yeast+time) character to ground its malts.
Pours red with minimal tan head. Overall amazing malt tones and toffee dominate the nose. Crisp finish and sweet taste make for an amazing beer

Reconsider what you think of ans Irish Red when you have this. Not much aroma, but wonderful toffee and caramel flavors linger. Robust and delicious with notes of chocolate and raisin to smooth the finish. Have 2.
Draft at the brewpub. Another very well made example of style. Malty, crisp and exceptionally clean. For all those Killians lovers, this is better. (#5109, 7/2/2013)

On tap at the brewpub, pours a clear dark red with an off white head, the aroma was pretty sweet with a good amount of caramel and malt, a little fruit as well though, the flavor has a lot of malt and caramel on the front end with a sweet but fruity finish at the same time, nice smooth mouthfeel, solid.
UPDATED: JUN 19, 2013 Reddish/ruby brown. Off-white head. Malty, caramel, toffee, roasty, chocolate, coffee. Medium body. Very nice.

On tap at Karben4 Brewery.  Deep copper with a thin tan head.  Aroma is on the malty side with plenty of caramel and toffee and a touch of peated malt to boot.  Malt bomb for sure with toffee, caramel, light nuttiness and a hint of peat.  Tasty.

On draught at the brewery taproom north of Madison, Wisconsin. Pours a clear dark reddish copper colored brew with a decent sized beige head that slowly dissipates and leaves behind some excellent lacing. Aroma of caramel malt, of hint of peat, light chocolate and a touch of walnut. Taste is medium to full bodied, soft carbonation with flavors of rich caramel malt, a hint of chocolate and toffee with some light yeast. Finish is quite smooth, semi-sweet malty at first and then a crisp finish with very little aftertaste. One of the few unAmericanized Irish ales Ive encountered in the US.

On tap at the brewpub - Pours deep amber with a thin off-white head. Nose is really bready with some muted sweetness, light peat, and nutty bread. Big caramel taste with a little smoky peat and big yeasty notes. Pretty thick in the mouth with smooth carbonation. Very impressive, for a style I dont normally like.
Growler shared by Brian.  Deep brown-burgundy..very dark for the style.  Smooth and malty, cherry amber malt and chocolate notes.  Really nice malt depth.  Clean, fresh, well executed.
